message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Predefined-Time Fault-Tolerant Consensus Tracking Control for Multi-UAV Systems With Prescribed Performance and Attitude Constraints
Paper Abstract: This paper focuses on the predefined-time faulttolerant consensus tracking control problem for multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) systems with prescribed performance and attitude constraints. The UAV systems are divided into the position subsystems and the attitude subsystems for consideration. In the position subsystem, a predefined-time consensus protocol is formulated by modifying the conventional prescribed performance control schemes. The advantage of our work is that the tracking errors can be consistently positive or negative during system operation while achieving the demanded tracking accuracy within the predefined time. In the attitude subsystem, an output-dependent universal barrier function is constructed to realize the attitude output constraints and remove the restrictive assumption that Euler angles should satisfy specific ranges in the existing results. Considering the actuators of UAVs are vulnerable to faults in hostile working environment, an adaptive compensation mechanism is developed to improve the fault tolerance of multi-UAV systems. Finally, the proposed control scheme is applied to power patrol inspection missions to verify its feasibility and effectiveness
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "fault-tolerant control"

Links: [{"title":"Fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Control reconfiguration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reconfiguration"},{"title":"Software fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Jakob Stoustrup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakob_Stoustrup"},{"title":"Fault detection and isolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_detection_and_isolation"},{"title":"Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-critical_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Fail-safe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fail-safe"},{"title":"Quantum error correction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_error_correction"},{"title":"Category:Fault-tolerant computer systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fault-tolerant_computer_systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of fault-tolerant control:

## Definition

Fault tolerance is the ability of a system to maintain proper operation despite failures or faults in one or more of its components. This capability is essential for high-availability, mission-critical, or even life-critical systems.

## Key Approaches

There are two main approaches to achieving fault-tolerant control:

1. **Control Reconfiguration**: This is used when severe faults, such as actuator or sensor outages, cause a break-up of the control loop, which must be restructured to prevent failure at the system level. In addition to loop restructuring, the controller parameters must be adjusted to accommodate changed plant dynamics.

2. **Fault Accommodation**: Fault accommodation is another common approach to achieve fault tolerance. In contrast to control reconfiguration, accommodation is limited to internal controller changes.

## Prerequisites

Before implementing control reconfiguration, it must be at least determined whether a fault has occurred (fault detection) and if so, which components are affected (fault isolation). Preferably, a model of the faulty plant should be provided (fault identification). These questions are addressed by fault diagnosis methods.

## Applications

Fault-tolerant control is applied in critical systems such as control systems for ordinary nuclear reactors and aircraft autopilots, where maintaining system operation despite failures is essential for safety.

## Search Results for "Consensus Tracking Control"

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about consensus tracking control:

### Consensus Dynamics and Control

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

### Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

### Related Coordination Problems

Related coordination problems include the rendezvous problem, synchronization, flocking, and formation control, which often rely on similar mathematical foundations and are studied under the broader umbrella of cooperative control.

### Multi-Agent Systems

The consensus problem in multi-agent systems aims to ensure that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.

The search results primarily focus on consensus dynamics as a control theory concept rather than a specific technique called "consensus tracking control," but the materials show that consensus control is a well-established field with applications in distributed systems, multi-agent robotics, and coordinated control systems.

## Search Results for "Unmanned Aerial Vehicle"

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of unmanned aerial vehicles:

### Definition and Basic Characteristics

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

### History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

### Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications, with drone market consultancy identifying 237 ways that drones revolutionize business across 15 industries including agriculture, energy, construction, and mining.

### Consumer Market

In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone at $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made, quickly capturing the consumer drone market with its affordability, accessibility, and user-friendly software.

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

### Consumer Market

Based on the web search results, "prescribed performance control" can refer to several concepts depending on context:

## Control Theory Context

In control theory, a feedback control system tends to maintain a prescribed relationship of one system variable to another by comparing functions of these variables and using the difference as a means of control.(no content)A closed loop control system is a control system possessing monitoring feedback, the deviation signal formed as a result of this feedback being used to control the action of a final control element in such a way as to tend to reduce the deviation to zero.

## H-Infinity Control

In advanced control engineering, the resulting controller is only optimal with respect to the prescribed cost function and does not necessarily represent the best controller in terms of the usual performance measures used to evaluate controllers such as settling time, energy expended, etc.

## Psychology Context

In psychology, motivational control is the self-regulatory mechanism by which individuals are able to act on prescribed behaviors to implement activities.

The specific meaning of "prescribed performance control" depends on the field of application—whether it's engineering/control systems, psychology, or organizational management. Could you provide more context about which domain you're interested in learning about?

Web search results for query: "barrier function control"

Links: [{"title":"Barrier function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_function"},{"title":"Barrier certificate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_certificate"},{"title":"Barrier (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Interior-point method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interior-point_method"},{"title":"Air barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_barriers"},{"title":"Traffic barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armco_barrier"},{"title":"Self-concordant function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-concordant_function"},{"title":"Schottky barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schottky_barrier"},{"title":"Crowd control barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowd_control_barrier"},{"title":"Rectangular potential barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_barrier"}]

Based on the search results, "barrier function control" can refer to different concepts depending on the context. Here are the main interpretations:

## Mathematical Optimization

In constrained optimization, a barrier function is a continuous function whose value increases to infinity as its argument approaches the boundary of the feasible region of an optimization problem. Such functions are used to replace inequality constraints by a penalizing term in the objective function that is easier to handle.(no content)The two most common types of barrier functions are inverse barrier functions and logarithmic barrier functions.(no content)Interior-point methods (also referred to as barrier methods or IPMs) are algorithms for solving linear and non-linear convex optimization problems.(no content)Self-concordant barrier functions are used to develop the barrier functions used in interior point methods for convex and nonlinear optimization.

## Control Systems (Barrier Certificates)

A barrier certificate or barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system. That is, a barrier function can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.(no content)One type is called a zeroing barrier function, while a barrier function that goes to infinity as the input approaches the boundary is called a reciprocal barrier function. Zeroing barrier functions may be preferred in embedded applications as they do not create unbounded values close to the set boundary.

These applications are fundamental to optimization theory and control system verification respectively.

Web search results for query: "Euler angles"

Links: [{"title":"Euler angles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_angles"},{"title":"Conversion between quaternions and Euler angles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversion_between_quaternions_and_Euler_angles"},{"title":"Euler's rotation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler's_rotation_theorem"},{"title":"Axis–angle representation","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axis–angle_representation"},{"title":"Leonhard Euler - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonhard_Euler"},{"title":"Gimbal lock - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gimbal_lock"},{"title":"Euler's formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler's_formula"},{"title":"Swiss 1.2-metre Leonhard Euler Telescope - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonhard_Euler_Telescope"},{"title":"Turn (angle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2pi"},{"title":"Euler–Rodrigues formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler%E2%80%93Rodrigues_formulas"}]

## Overview of Euler Angles

Euler angles are three angles introduced by Leonhard Euler to describe the orientation of a rigid body with respect to a fixed coordinate system.(no content)They can also represent the orientation of a mobile frame of reference in physics or the orientation of a general basis in three dimensional linear algebra.

## Key Characteristics

Three consecutive elemental rotations (rotations about the axes of a coordinate system) are always sufficient to reach any target frame.(no content)Euler angles are typically denoted as α, β, γ, or ψ, θ, φ.

### Types of Euler Angles

There exist twelve possible sequences of rotation axes, divided in two groups: Proper Euler angles (z-x-z, x-y-x, y-z-y, z-y-z, x-z-x, y-x-y) and Tait–Bryan angles (x-y-z, y-z-x, z-x-y, x-z-y, z-y-x, y-x-z).(no content)Tait–Bryan angles are also called Cardan angles; nautical angles; heading, elevation, and bank; or yaw, pitch, and roll.

## Important Limitation: Gimbal Lock

The problem of gimbal lock appears when one uses Euler angles in applied mathematics; developers of 3D computer programs, such as 3D modeling, embedded navigation systems, and video games must take care to avoid it.(no content)Euler angles provide a means for giving a numerical description of any rotation in three-dimensional space using three numbers, but not only is this description not unique, but there are some points where not every change in the target space (rotations) can be realized by a change in the source space (Euler angles).

There exist twelve possible sequences of rotation axes, divided in two groups: Proper Euler angles (z-x-z, x-y-x, y-z-y, z-y-z, x-z-x, y-x-y) and Tait–Bryan angles (x-y-z, y-z-x, z-x-y, x-z-y, z-y-x, y-x-z).(no content)Tait–Bryan angles are also called Cardan angles; nautical angles; heading, elevation, and bank; or yaw, pitch, and roll.

## Important Limitation: Gimbal Lock

The problem of gimbal lock appears when one uses Euler angles in applied mathematics; developers of 3D computer programs, such as 3D modeling, embedded navigation systems, and video games must take care to avoid it.(no content)Euler angles provide a means for giving a numerical description of any rotation in three-dimensional space using three numbers, but not only is this description not unique, but there are some points where not every change in the target space (rotations) can be realized by a change in the source space (Euler angles).

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Technologies and Methodologies Extracted:**

1. **Consensus dynamics** (proposes) - A new predefined-time consensus protocol for multi-agent systems
2. **Robust control** (uses) - The prescribed performance control scheme builds on this theory
3. **Fault tolerance** (proposes) - An adaptive compensation mechanism for UAV fault tolerance
4. **Barrier function** (proposes) - A novel output-dependent universal barrier function for attitude constraints
5. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (uses) - The application domain for the control schemes
6. **Euler angles** (uses) - Used in attitude control, with paper removing restrictive assumptions

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully

The JSON file has been updated with all triples, Wikipedia URLs, and relevance descriptions. The paper contains 3 methods, 2 concepts, and 1 tool, demonstrating both novel contributions and solid grounding in existing control theory fundamentals.
